content.content:
1	# Atriumn SDK for Go
     2	
     3	This repository contains the official Go SDKs for Atriumn services.
     4	
     5	## Available SDKs
     6	
     7	### [Auth](/auth)
     8	
     9	Go client for the Atriumn Authentication Service. Provides functionality for:
    10	
    11	- Client Credentials authentication
    12	- User signup, login, and management
    13	- Password reset workflows
    14	
    15	### [Storage](/storage)
    16	
    17	Go client for the Atriumn Storage Service. Provides functionality for:
    18	
    19	- Generating pre-signed S3 URLs for file uploads
    20	- Generating pre-signed S3 URLs for file downloads
    21	- JWT token-based authentication
    22	
    23	## Installation
    24	
    25	```bash
    26	# Install the auth client
    27	go get github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/auth
    28	
    29	# Install the storage client
    30	go get github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/storage
    31	```
    32	
    33	## Development
    34	
    35	### Testing
    36	
    37	```bash
    38	# Run all tests
    39	go test -v ./...
    40	
    41	# Test a specific package
    42	go test -v ./auth
    43	go test -v ./storage
    44	```
    45	
    46	## License
    47	
    48	[MIT](LICENSE)
    49

1	# Atriumn Auth Client
     2	
     3	A Go client library for the Atriumn Authentication Service. This package provides an easy way to interact with the Atriumn Auth API from other Go services.
     4	
     5	## Installation
     6	
     7	```bash
     8	go get github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/auth
     9	```
    10	
    11	## Usage
    12	
    13	### Creating a Client
    14	
    15	```go
    16	import (
    17	    "context"
    18	    "fmt"
    19	    "log"
    20	    "time"
    21	
    22	    "github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/auth"
    23	)
    24	
    25	func main() {
    26	    // Create a client with default settings
    27	    client, err := auth.NewClient("https://api.example.com")
    28	    if err != nil {
    29	        log.Fatalf("Failed to create client: %v", err)
    30	    }
    31	
    32	    // Or create with custom options
    33	    customClient, err := auth.NewClientWithOptions(
    34	        "https://api.example.com",
    35	        auth.WithHTTPClient(&http.Client{Timeout: 30 * time.Second}),
    36	        auth.WithUserAgent("my-service/1.0"),
    37	    )
    38	    if err != nil {
    39	        log.Fatalf("Failed to create client: %v", err)
    40	    }
    41	
    42	    // Use the client...
    43	}
    44	```
    45	
    46	### Health Check
    47	
    48	```go
    49	ctx := context.Background()
    50	health, err := client.Health(ctx)
    51	if err != nil {
    52	    log.Fatalf("Health check failed: %v", err)
    53	}
    54	fmt.Printf("API status: %s\n", health.Status)
    55	```
    56	
    57	### Client Credentials Flow
    58	
    59	```go
    60	ctx := context.Background()
    61	token, err := client.GetClientCredentialsToken(
    62	    ctx,
    63	    "client-id",
    64	    "client-secret",
    65	    "requested-scope", // Optional, can be empty string
    66	)
    67	if err != nil {
    68	    log.Fatalf("Failed to get token: %v", err)
    69	}
    70	
    71	fmt.Printf("Access Token: %s\n", token.AccessToken)
    72	fmt.Printf("Token Type: %s\n", token.TokenType)
    73	fmt.Printf("Expires In: %d seconds\n", token.ExpiresIn)
    74	```
    75	
    76	### User Signup
    77	
    78	```go
    79	ctx := context.Background()
    80	attributes := map[string]string{
    81	    "name": "John Doe",
    82	    "custom:role": "user",
    83	}
    84	result, err := client.SignupUser(ctx, "user@example.com", "password123", attributes)
    85	if err != nil {
    86	    log.Fatalf("Signup failed: %v", err)
    87	}
    88	
    89	fmt.Printf("User ID: %s\n", result.UserID)
    90	```
    91	
    92	### User Login
    93	
    94	```go
    95	ctx := context.Background()
    96	token, err := client.LoginUser(ctx, "user@example.com", "password123")
    97	if err != nil {
    98	    log.Fatalf("Login failed: %v", err)
    99	}
   100	
   101	fmt.Printf("Access Token: %s\n", token.AccessToken)
   102	fmt.Printf("ID Token: %s\n", token.IDToken)
   103	fmt.Printf("Refresh Token: %s\n", token.RefreshToken)
   104	```
   105	
   106	### User Logout
   107	
   108	```go
   109	ctx := context.Background()
   110	err := client.LogoutUser(ctx, "access-token-from-login")
   111	if err != nil {
   112	    log.Fatalf("Logout failed: %v", err)
   113	}
   114	
   115	fmt.Println("User logged out successfully")
   116	```
   117	
   118	### Password Reset
   119	
   120	```go
   121	ctx := context.Background()
   122	
   123	// Request password reset
   124	response, err := client.RequestPasswordReset(ctx, "user@example.com")
   125	if err != nil {
   126	    log.Fatalf("Password reset request failed: %v", err)
   127	}
   128	
   129	fmt.Printf("Code sent to: %s\n", response.CodeDeliveryDetails.Destination)
   130	
   131	// Confirm password reset with code
   132	err = client.ConfirmPasswordReset(ctx, "user@example.com", "123456", "new-password")
   133	if err != nil {
   134	    log.Fatalf("Password reset confirmation failed: %v", err)
   135	}
   136	
   137	fmt.Println("Password reset successfully")
   138	```
   139	
   140	### Error Handling
   141	
   142	```go
   143	ctx := context.Background()
   144	_, err := client.LoginUser(ctx, "wrong@example.com", "wrong-password")
   145	if err != nil {
   146	    // Check if it's an API error
   147	    if apiErr, ok := err.(*auth.ErrorResponse); ok {
   148	        fmt.Printf("API Error: %s - %s\n", apiErr.Error, apiErr.Description)
   149	    } else {
   150	        fmt.Printf("Network or other error: %v\n", err)
   151	    }
   152	}
   153	```
   154	
   155	## Development
   156	
   157	### Running Tests
   158	
   159	```bash
   160	cd atriumn-sdk-go
   161	go test -v ./auth
   162	```
   163

1	# Atriumn Storage SDK
     2	
     3	The Atriumn Storage SDK provides a Go client for interacting with the Atriumn Storage service. It allows you to generate pre-signed URLs for uploading and downloading files from S3.
     4	
     5	## Installation
     6	
     7	```bash
     8	go get github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go
     9	```
    10	
    11	## Usage
    12	
    13	### Initializing the Client
    14	
    15	```go
    16	import (
    17	    "github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/storage"
    18	)
    19	
    20	// Create a client with default options
    21	client, err := storage.NewClient("https://api.atriumn.com/storage")
    22	if err != nil {
    23	    // Handle error
    24	}
    25	
    26	// Create a client with custom options
    27	client, err := storage.NewClientWithOptions("https://api.atriumn.com/storage",
    28	    storage.WithHTTPClient(&http.Client{Timeout: 20 * time.Second}),
    29	    storage.WithUserAgent("custom-user-agent/1.0"),
    30	)
    31	```
    32	
    33	### Authentication
    34	
    35	The storage service requires JWT authentication. You need to provide a token provider that implements the `TokenProvider` interface:
    36	
    37	```go
    38	// Example token provider using the auth package
    39	type AuthTokenProvider struct {
    40	    authClient *auth.Client
    41	    clientID   string
    42	    clientSecret string
    43	}
    44	
    45	func (a *AuthTokenProvider) GetToken(ctx context.Context) (string, error) {
    46	    // Get token from the auth service
    47	    tokenResp, err := a.authClient.GetClientCredentialsToken(ctx, a.clientID, a.clientSecret, "storage")
    48	    if err != nil {
    49	        return "", err
    50	    }
    51	    return tokenResp.AccessToken, nil
    52	}
    53	
    54	// Create a client with the token provider
    55	tokenProvider := &AuthTokenProvider{
    56	    authClient: authClient,
    57	    clientID: "your-client-id",
    58	    clientSecret: "your-client-secret",
    59	}
    60	client, err := storage.NewClientWithOptions("https://api.atriumn.com/storage",
    61	    storage.WithTokenProvider(tokenProvider),
    62	)
    63	```
    64	
    65	### Generating an Upload URL
    66	
    67	```go
    68	// Generate a pre-signed URL for uploading a file
    69	uploadResp, err := client.GenerateUploadURL(ctx, &storage.GenerateUploadURLRequest{
    70	    Filename:    "document.pdf",
    71	    ContentType: "application/pdf",
    72	})
    73	if err != nil {
    74	    // Handle error
    75	}
    76	
    77	// Use the uploadResp.UploadURL with the uploadResp.HTTPMethod (typically PUT)
    78	// to upload the file to S3
    79	```
    80	
    81	### Generating a Download URL
    82	
    83	```go
    84	// Generate a pre-signed URL for downloading a file
    85	downloadResp, err := client.GenerateDownloadURL(ctx, &storage.GenerateDownloadURLRequest{
    86	    S3Key: "tenant-123/files/document.pdf",
    87	})
    88	if err != nil {
    89	    // Handle error
    90	}
    91	
    92	// Use the downloadResp.DownloadURL with the downloadResp.HTTPMethod (typically GET)
    93	// to download the file from S3
    94	
    95	// Alternatively, use the convenience method with just the S3 key
    96	downloadResp, err := client.GenerateDownloadURLFromKey(ctx, "tenant-123/files/document.pdf")
    97	if err != nil {
    98	    // Handle error
    99	}
   100	```
   101	
   102	### Error Handling
   103	
   104	The SDK returns errors that implement the standard error interface. For API errors, the error will be of type `*storage.ErrorResponse`:
   105	
   106	```go
   107	resp, err := client.GenerateDownloadURL(ctx, req)
   108	if err != nil {
   109	    if apiErr, ok := err.(*storage.ErrorResponse); ok {
   110	        // Handle API error
   111	        fmt.Printf("API Error: %s - %s\n", apiErr.ErrorCode, apiErr.Description)
   112	    } else {
   113	        // Handle other errors
   114	        fmt.Printf("Error: %v\n", err)
   115	    }
   116	    return
   117	}
   118	```
   119	
   120	## Complete Example
   121	
   122	Here's a complete example showing how to upload a file using the storage SDK:
   123	
   124	```go
   125	package main
   126	
   127	import (
   128	    "context"
   129	    "fmt"
   130	    "io"
   131	    "net/http"
   132	    "os"
   133	    "time"
   134	
   135	    "github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/auth"
   136	    "github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/storage"
   137	)
   138	
   139	// Simple token provider that caches tokens
   140	type CachingTokenProvider struct {
   141	    authClient   *auth.Client
   142	    clientID     string
   143	    clientSecret string
   144	    token        string
   145	    expiresAt    time.Time
   146	}
   147	
   148	func (c *CachingTokenProvider) GetToken(ctx context.Context) (string, error) {
   149	    // If we have a valid token, return it
   150	    if c.token != "" && time.Now().Before(c.expiresAt) {
   151	        return c.token, nil
   152	    }
   153	
   154	    // Otherwise, get a new token
   155	    tokenResp, err := c.authClient.GetClientCredentialsToken(ctx, c.clientID, c.clientSecret, "storage")
   156	    if err != nil {
   157	        return "", err
   158	    }
   159	
   160	    // Cache the token with a buffer before expiry
   161	    c.token = tokenResp.AccessToken
   162	    c.expiresAt = time.Now().Add(time.Duration(tokenResp.ExpiresIn-300) * time.Second)
   163	
   164	    return c.token, nil
   165	}
   166	
   167	func main() {
   168	    ctx := context.Background()
   169	
   170	    // Initialize auth client
   171	    authClient, err := auth.NewClient("https://api.atriumn.com/auth")
   172	    if err != nil {
   173	        fmt.Printf("Error creating auth client: %v\n", err)
   174	        return
   175	    }
   176	
   177	    // Create token provider
   178	    tokenProvider := &CachingTokenProvider{
   179	        authClient:   authClient,
   180	        clientID:     "your-client-id",
   181	        clientSecret: "your-client-secret",
   182	    }
   183	
   184	    // Initialize storage client with token provider
   185	    storageClient, err := storage.NewClientWithOptions("https://api.atriumn.com/storage",
   186	        storage.WithTokenProvider(tokenProvider),
   187	    )
   188	    if err != nil {
   189	        fmt.Printf("Error creating storage client: %v\n", err)
   190	        return
   191	    }
   192	
   193	    // 1. Generate upload URL
   194	    uploadResp, err := storageClient.GenerateUploadURL(ctx, &storage.GenerateUploadURLRequest{
   195	        Filename:    "example.pdf",
   196	        ContentType: "application/pdf",
   197	    })
   198	    if err != nil {
   199	        fmt.Printf("Error generating upload URL: %v\n", err)
   200	        return
   201	    }
   202	
   203	    fmt.Printf("Generated upload URL: %s\n", uploadResp.UploadURL)
   204	
   205	    // 2. Upload file using the pre-signed URL
   206	    file, err := os.Open("path/to/your/file.pdf")
   207	    if err != nil {
   208	        fmt.Printf("Error opening file: %v\n", err)
   209	        return
   210	    }
   211	    defer file.Close()
   212	
   213	    req, err := http.NewRequestWithContext(ctx, uploadResp.HTTPMethod, uploadResp.UploadURL, file)
   214	    if err != nil {
   215	        fmt.Printf("Error creating upload request: %v\n", err)
   216	        return
   217	    }
   218	    req.Header.Set("Content-Type", "application/pdf")
   219	
   220	    resp, err := http.DefaultClient.Do(req)
   221	    if err != nil {
   222	        fmt.Printf("Error uploading file: %v\n", err)
   223	        return
   224	    }
   225	    defer resp.Body.Close()
   226	
   227	    if resp.StatusCode != http.StatusOK {
   228	        body, _ := io.ReadAll(resp.Body)
   229	        fmt.Printf("Upload failed with status %d: %s\n", resp.StatusCode, string(body))
   230	        return
   231	    }
   232	
   233	    fmt.Println("File uploaded successfully!")
   234	
   235	    // 3. Generate download URL (assuming we know the S3 key)
   236	    s3Key := "tenant/files/example.pdf" // The actual S3 key might be generated by the service
   237	
   238	    downloadResp, err := storageClient.GenerateDownloadURLFromKey(ctx, s3Key)
   239	    if err != nil {
   240	        fmt.Printf("Error generating download URL: %v\n", err)
   241	        return
   242	    }
   243	
   244	    fmt.Printf("Generated download URL: %s\n", downloadResp.DownloadURL)
   245	}
   246	```

1	# Atriumn AI SDK
     2	
     3	This package provides a Go client for interacting with the Atriumn AI API. It enables managing prompts and related configurations through a simple, idiomatic Go interface.
     4	
     5	## Installation
     6	
     7	```bash
     8	go get github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go
     9	```
    10	
    11	## Usage
    12	
    13	### Initialize the Client
    14	
    15	```go
    16	import (
    17	    "context"
    18	    "github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/ai"
    19	)
    20	
    21	// Create a new client with the default configuration
    22	client, err := ai.NewClient("https://api.atriumn.ai")
    23	if err != nil {
    24	    // Handle error
    25	}
    26	
    27	// Create a client with custom options
    28	httpClient := &http.Client{
    29	    Timeout: 30 * time.Second,
    30	}
    31	
    32	client, err := ai.NewClientWithOptions("https://api.atriumn.ai",
    33	    ai.WithHTTPClient(httpClient),
    34	    ai.WithUserAgent("my-custom-agent/1.0"),
    35	)
    36	if err != nil {
    37	    // Handle error
    38	}
    39	```
    40	
    41	### Create a Prompt
    42	
    43	```go
    44	ctx := context.Background()
    45	
    46	// Define a new prompt
    47	createRequest := &ai.CreatePromptRequest{
    48	    Name:        "Customer Service Greeting",
    49	    Description: "A friendly greeting for customer service interactions",
    50	    Template:    "Hello {{customer_name}}, thank you for contacting us. How can I help you today?",
    51	    Variables: []ai.PromptVariable{
    52	        {
    53	            Name:         "customer_name",
    54	            Description:  "The name of the customer",
    55	            DefaultValue: "valued customer",
    56	            Required:     true,
    57	        },
    58	    },
    59	    Tags: []string{"customer-service", "greeting"},
    60	}
    61	
    62	prompt, err := client.CreatePrompt(ctx, createRequest)
    63	if err != nil {
    64	    // Handle error
    65	}
    66	
    67	fmt.Printf("Created prompt: %s (ID: %s)\n", prompt.Name, prompt.ID)
    68	```
    69	
    70	### Get a Prompt
    71	
    72	```go
    73	prompt, err := client.GetPrompt(ctx, "prompt-123")
    74	if err != nil {
    75	    // Handle error
    76	}
    77	
    78	fmt.Printf("Prompt: %s\nTemplate: %s\n", prompt.Name, prompt.Template)
    79	```
    80	
    81	### Update a Prompt
    82	
    83	```go
    84	// Note: We use pointers for fields that can be updated
    85	// to distinguish between zero values and not provided fields
    86	newName := "Updated Greeting"
    87	newTemplate := "Hello {{customer_name}}, welcome to our support! How may I assist you today?"
    88	
    89	updateRequest := &ai.UpdatePromptRequest{
    90	    Name:     &newName,
    91	    Template: &newTemplate,
    92	    Tags:     []string{"customer-service", "greeting", "support"},
    93	}
    94	
    95	updatedPrompt, err := client.UpdatePrompt(ctx, "prompt-123", updateRequest)
    96	if err != nil {
    97	    // Handle error
    98	}
    99	
   100	fmt.Printf("Updated prompt: %s\nNew template: %s\n",
   101	    updatedPrompt.Name, updatedPrompt.Template)
   102	```
   103	
   104	### Delete a Prompt
   105	
   106	```go
   107	err := client.DeletePrompt(ctx, "prompt-123")
   108	if err != nil {
   109	    // Handle error
   110	}
   111	fmt.Println("Prompt deleted successfully")
   112	```
   113	
   114	### List Prompts
   115	
   116	```go
   117	// List all prompts
   118	prompts, nextToken, err := client.ListPrompts(ctx, nil)
   119	if err != nil {
   120	    // Handle error
   121	}
   122	
   123	fmt.Printf("Found %d prompts\n", len(prompts))
   124	for _, p := range prompts {
   125	    fmt.Printf("- %s (ID: %s)\n", p.Name, p.ID)
   126	}
   127	
   128	// List prompts with filtering and pagination
   129	options := &ai.ListPromptsOptions{
   130	    ModelID:    "model-abc",
   131	    Tags:       []string{"customer-service"},
   132	    MaxResults: 10,
   133	}
   134	
   135	prompts, nextToken, err := client.ListPrompts(ctx, options)
   136	if err != nil {
   137	    // Handle error
   138	}
   139	
   140	// For pagination, use the nextToken in subsequent requests
   141	if nextToken != "" {
   142	    nextPageOptions := &ai.ListPromptsOptions{
   143	        ModelID:    "model-abc",
   144	        Tags:       []string{"customer-service"},
   145	        MaxResults: 10,
   146	        NextToken:  nextToken,
   147	    }
   148	
   149	    morePrompts, nextToken, err := client.ListPrompts(ctx, nextPageOptions)
   150	    // ...
   151	}
   152	```
   153	
   154	## Error Handling
   155	
   156	The client methods return specific errors that can be further inspected using the standard error handling mechanisms in Go:
   157	
   158	```go
   159	prompt, err := client.GetPrompt(ctx, "non-existent-prompt")
   160	if err != nil {
   161	    // Check if it's an API error
   162	    if apiErr, ok := err.(*apierror.ErrorResponse); ok {
   163	        switch apiErr.ErrorCode {
   164	        case "not_found":
   165	            fmt.Println("The specified prompt was not found")
   166	        case "unauthorized":
   167	            fmt.Println("Authentication failed")
   168	        default:
   169	            fmt.Printf("API error: %s - %s\n", apiErr.ErrorCode, apiErr.Description)
   170	        }
   171	    } else {
   172	        // Handle network or other client-side errors
   173	        fmt.Printf("Error: %v\n", err)
   174	    }
   175	}
   176	```
   177	
   178	## Authentication
   179	
   180	This client is designed to work with AWS IAM SigV4 request signing. You should provide an `http.Client` that is configured with the appropriate credentials:
   181	
   182	```go
   183	import (
   184	    "context"
   185	    "github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/ai"
   186	    "github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/aws"
   187	    "github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/config"
   188	    "github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/credentials"
   189	    v4 "github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/aws/signer/v4"
   190	)
   191	
   192	// Load AWS credentials
   193	cfg, err := config.LoadDefaultConfig(context.TODO(),
   194	    config.WithRegion("us-west-2"),
   195	    config.WithCredentialsProvider(credentials.NewStaticCredentialsProvider(
   196	        "YOUR_ACCESS_KEY", "YOUR_SECRET_KEY", "",
   197	    )),
   198	)
   199	if err != nil {
   200	    // Handle error
   201	}
   202	
   203	// Create a transport that signs requests with SigV4
   204	transport := &http.Transport{}
   205	signingTransport := v4.NewSigningTransport(transport, cfg.Credentials, "execute-api", "us-west-2")
   206	
   207	// Create HTTP client with the signing transport
   208	httpClient := &http.Client{
   209	    Transport: signingTransport,
   210	}
   211	
   212	// Create the Atriumn AI client with the signing HTTP client
   213	client, err := ai.NewClientWithOptions("https://api.atriumn.ai",
   214	    ai.WithHTTPClient(httpClient),
   215	)
   216	```

1	# Atriumn Ingest Client
     2	
     3	A Go client library for the Atriumn Ingest Service. This package provides an easy way to interact with the Atriumn Ingest API from other Go services.
     4	
     5	## Installation
     6	
     7	```bash
     8	go get github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/ingest
     9	```
    10	
    11	## Usage
    12	
    13	### Creating a Client
    14	
    15	```go
    16	import (
    17	    "context"
    18	    "fmt"
    19	    "log"
    20	    "time"
    21	    "os"
    22	
    23	    "github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/auth"
    24	    "github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/ingest"
    25	)
    26	
    27	func main() {
    28	    // Create a client with default settings
    29	    client, err := ingest.NewClient("https://api.example.com")
    30	    if err != nil {
    31	        log.Fatalf("Failed to create client: %v", err)
    32	    }
    33	
    34	    // Or create with custom options
    35	    customClient, err := ingest.NewClientWithOptions(
    36	        "https://api.example.com",
    37	        ingest.WithHTTPClient(&http.Client{Timeout: 30 * time.Second}),
    38	        ingest.WithUserAgent("my-service/1.0"),
    39	    )
    40	    if err != nil {
    41	        log.Fatalf("Failed to create client: %v", err)
    42	    }
    43	
    44	    // Use the client...
    45	}
    46	```
    47	
    48	### Authentication
    49	
    50	The ingest service requires JWT authentication. You need to provide a token provider that implements the `TokenProvider` interface:
    51	
    52	```go
    53	// Example token provider using the auth package
    54	type AuthTokenProvider struct {
    55	    authClient   *auth.Client
    56	    clientID     string
    57	    clientSecret string
    58	}
    59	
    60	func (a *AuthTokenProvider) GetToken(ctx context.Context) (string, error) {
    61	    // Get token from the auth service
    62	    tokenResp, err := a.authClient.GetClientCredentialsToken(ctx, a.clientID, a.clientSecret, "ingest")
    63	    if err != nil {
    64	        return "", err
    65	    }
    66	    return tokenResp.AccessToken, nil
    67	}
    68	
    69	// Create a client with the token provider
    70	authClient, _ := auth.NewClient("https://auth.example.com")
    71	tokenProvider := &AuthTokenProvider{
    72	    authClient:   authClient,
    73	    clientID:     "your-client-id",
    74	    clientSecret: "your-client-secret",
    75	}
    76	
    77	client, err := ingest.NewClientWithOptions(
    78	    "https://api.example.com",
    79	    ingest.WithTokenProvider(tokenProvider),
    80	)
    81	```
    82	
    83	### Ingesting Text
    84	
    85	```go
    86	ctx := context.Background()
    87	
    88	// Create the request
    89	request := &ingest.IngestTextRequest{
    90	    TenantID: "tenant-123",
    91	    UserID:   "user-456",
    92	    Content:  "This is the text content to be ingested.",
    93	    Metadata: map[string]string{
    94	        "source": "manual-input",
    95	        "category": "notes",
    96	    },
    97	}
    98	
    99	// Send the request
   100	response, err := client.IngestText(ctx, request)
   101	if err != nil {
   102	    log.Fatalf("Failed to ingest text: %v", err)
   103	}
   104	
   105	fmt.Printf("Ingestion ID: %s\n", response.ID)
   106	fmt.Printf("Status: %s\n", response.Status)
   107	```
   108	
   109	### Ingesting URL
   110	
   111	```go
   112	ctx := context.Background()
   113	
   114	// Create the request
   115	request := &ingest.IngestURLRequest{
   116	    TenantID: "tenant-123",
   117	    UserID:   "user-456",
   118	    URL:      "https://example.com/document.pdf",
   119	    Metadata: map[string]string{
   120	        "source": "web",
   121	        "category": "document",
   122	    },
   123	}
   124	
   125	// Send the request
   126	response, err := client.IngestURL(ctx, request)
   127	if err != nil {
   128	    log.Fatalf("Failed to ingest URL: %v", err)
   129	}
   130	
   131	fmt.Printf("Ingestion ID: %s\n", response.ID)
   132	fmt.Printf("Status: %s\n", response.Status)
   133	```
   134	
   135	### Uploading Files (Two-Step Process)
   136	
   137	The SDK uses a two-step process for file uploads:
   138	
   139	1. Request a pre-signed URL by sending file metadata
   140	2. Upload the file content directly to the pre-signed URL
   141	
   142	```go
   143	ctx := context.Background()
   144	
   145	// Open the file
   146	file, err := os.Open("document.pdf")
   147	if err != nil {
   148	    log.Fatalf("Failed to open file: %v", err)
   149	}
   150	defer file.Close()
   151	
   152	// Step 1: Request a file upload URL
   153	uploadRequest := &ingest.RequestFileUploadRequest{
   154	    Filename:    "document.pdf",
   155	    ContentType: "application/pdf",
   156	    TenantID:    "tenant-123",
   157	    UserID:      "user-456",
   158	    Metadata: map[string]string{
   159	        "source": "local-drive",
   160	        "category": "document",
   161	    },
   162	}
   163	
   164	uploadResponse, err := client.RequestFileUpload(ctx, uploadRequest)
   165	if err != nil {
   166	    log.Fatalf("Failed to request file upload URL: %v", err)
   167	}
   168	
   169	fmt.Printf("Content ID: %s\n", uploadResponse.ContentID)
   170	fmt.Printf("Upload URL: %s\n", uploadResponse.UploadURL)
   171	
   172	// Ensure file cursor is at the beginning
   173	if _, err := file.Seek(0, 0); err != nil {
   174	    log.Fatalf("Failed to seek to beginning of file: %v", err)
   175	}
   176	
   177	// Step 2: Upload the file directly to the pre-signed URL
   178	resp, err := client.UploadToURL(ctx, uploadResponse.UploadURL, "application/pdf", file)
   179	if err != nil {
   180	    log.Fatalf("Failed to upload file: %v", err)
   181	}
   182	defer resp.Body.Close()
   183	
   184	fmt.Printf("Upload status: %d\n", resp.StatusCode)
   185	```
   186	
   187	### Error Handling
   188	
   189	The SDK returns errors that implement the standard error interface. For API errors, the error will be of type `*ingest.ErrorResponse`:
   190	
   191	```go
   192	resp, err := client.IngestText(ctx, request)
   193	if err != nil {
   194	    if apiErr, ok := err.(*ingest.ErrorResponse); ok {
   195	        // Handle API error
   196	        fmt.Printf("API Error: %s - %s\n", apiErr.ErrorCode, apiErr.Description)
   197	    } else {
   198	        // Handle other errors
   199	        fmt.Printf("Error: %v\n", err)
   200	    }
   201	    return
   202	}
   203	```
   204
Now let's look at the examples to understand how the SDKs are used in practice:

content.content:
1	package main
     2	
     3	import (
     4		"context"
     5		"fmt"
     6		"log"
     7		"os"
     8		"path/filepath"
     9	
    10		"github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/ingest"
    11	)
    12	
    13	func main() {
    14		// Check if a filename was provided
    15		if len(os.Args) < 2 {
    16			fmt.Println("Usage: go run file_upload.go <file_to_upload>")
    17			os.Exit(1)
    18		}
    19	
    20		// Get the file path from command line arguments
    21		filePath := os.Args[1]
    22	
    23		// Initialize the ingest client
    24		client, err := ingest.NewClient("https://api.atriumn.io")
    25		if err != nil {
    26			log.Fatalf("Failed to create client: %v", err)
    27		}
    28	
    29		// Open the file
    30		file, err := os.Open(filePath)
    31		if err != nil {
    32			log.Fatalf("Failed to open file: %v", err)
    33		}
    34		defer file.Close()
    35	
    36		// Get file information
    37		fileInfo, err := file.Stat()
    38		if err != nil {
    39			log.Fatalf("Failed to get file info: %v", err)
    40		}
    41	
    42		// Determine content type based on file extension
    43		// In a production application, you might want to use a more robust method
    44		// such as http.DetectContentType or a library like github.com/gabriel-vasile/mimetype
    45		contentType := getContentType(filePath)
    46	
    47		fmt.Printf("Uploading file: %s (Size: %d bytes, Type: %s)\n", filepath.Base(filePath), fileInfo.Size(), contentType)
    48	
    49		// Step 1: Request a file upload URL
    50		uploadRequest := &ingest.RequestFileUploadRequest{
    51			Filename:    filepath.Base(filePath),
    52			ContentType: contentType,
    53			// Add tenant ID and user ID if required by your application
    54			// TenantID: "your-tenant-id",
    55			// UserID: "your-user-id",
    56			Metadata: map[string]string{
    57				"source": "sdk-example",
    58				"size":   fmt.Sprintf("%d", fileInfo.Size()),
    59			},
    60		}
    61	
    62		uploadResponse, err := client.RequestFileUpload(context.Background(), uploadRequest)
    63		if err != nil {
    64			log.Fatalf("Failed to request upload URL: %v", err)
    65		}
    66	
    67		fmt.Printf("Upload URL obtained. Content ID: %s, Status: %s\n", uploadResponse.ContentID, uploadResponse.Status)
    68	
    69		// Rewind the file to the beginning for upload
    70		if _, err := file.Seek(0, 0); err != nil {
    71			log.Fatalf("Failed to seek to beginning of file: %v", err)
    72		}
    73	
    74		// Step 2: Upload the file content directly to the pre-signed URL
    75		fmt.Println("Uploading file content to the pre-signed URL...")
    76		resp, err := client.UploadToURL(context.Background(), uploadResponse.UploadURL, contentType, file)
    77		if err != nil {
    78			log.Fatalf("Failed to upload file: %v", err)
    79		}
    80		defer resp.Body.Close()
    81	
    82		fmt.Printf("Upload complete! Status: %d\n", resp.StatusCode)
    83		fmt.Printf("Content item ID: %s\n", uploadResponse.ContentID)
    84	}
    85	
    86	// getContentType returns a MIME type based on the file extension
    87	func getContentType(filename string) string {
    88		ext := filepath.Ext(filename)
    89		switch ext {
    90		case ".pdf":
    91			return "application/pdf"
    92		case ".txt":
    93			return "text/plain"
    94		case ".json":
    95			return "application/json"
    96		case ".csv":
    97			return "text/csv"
    98		case ".png":
    99			return "image/png"
   100		case ".jpg", ".jpeg":
   101			return "image/jpeg"
   102		case ".gif":
   103			return "image/gif"
   104		case ".mp4":
   105			return "video/mp4"
   106		default:
   107			// Default to binary data if we can't determine the type
   108			return "application/octet-stream"
   109		}
   110	}

1	// This example demonstrates how to use the Atriumn AI client
     2	// to perform CRUD operations on prompts.
     3	package main
     4

     9		"time"

    11		"github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/ai"

    14	func main() {

    16		apiEndpoint := "https://api.atriumn.ai"
    17	
    18		// Create a client with default options
    19		client, err := ai.NewClient(apiEndpoint)
    20		if err != nil {
    21			fmt.Printf("Error creating client: %v\n", err)

    23		}

    25		// For a client with custom options:
    26		// client, err := ai.NewClientWithOptions(

    28		//     ai.WithHTTPClient(&http.Client{Timeout: 30 * time.Second}),
    29		//     ai.WithUserAgent("custom-app/1.0"),
    30		// )
    31	
    32		// Create a context with timeout
    33		ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), 10*time.Second)
    34		defer cancel()
    35	
    36		// Create a new prompt
    37		createPromptExample(ctx, client)

    39		// Get a prompt

    54	
    55	func createPromptExample(ctx context.Context, client *ai.Client) {
    56		fmt.Println("\n=== Creating a new prompt ===")
    57	
    58		// Define the prompt creation request
    59		createRequest := &ai.CreatePromptRequest{
    60			Name:        "Product Description Generator",
    61			Description: "Generates compelling product descriptions for e-commerce",
    62			Template:    "Create a compelling description for {{product_name}} that highlights its {{feature}} and appeals to {{target_audience}}.",
    63			ModelID:     "gpt-4",
    64			Parameters: map[string]interface{}{
    65				"temperature": 0.7,
    66				"max_tokens":  300,
    67			},
    68			Variables: []ai.PromptVariable{
    69				{
    70					Name:         "product_name",
    71					Description:  "The name of the product",
    72					Required:     true,
    73				},
    74				{
    75					Name:         "feature",
    76					Description:  "Main feature to highlight",
    77					DefaultValue: "unique selling point",
    78					Required:     true,
    79				},
    80				{
    81					Name:         "target_audience",
    82					Description:  "Target customer demographic",
    83					DefaultValue: "general consumers",
    84					Required:     false,
    85				},
    86			},
    87			Tags: []string{"e-commerce", "marketing", "product"},
    88		}
    89	
    90		prompt, err := client.CreatePrompt(ctx, createRequest)
    91		if err != nil {
    92			fmt.Printf("Error creating prompt: %v\n", err)
    93			return
    94		}
    95	
    96		fmt.Printf("Created prompt successfully:\n")
    97		fmt.Printf("  ID: %s\n", prompt.ID)
    98		fmt.Printf("  Name: %s\n", prompt.Name)
    99		fmt.Printf("  Version: %d\n", prompt.Version)
   100		fmt.Printf("  Created: %s\n", prompt.CreatedAt)
   101	}
   102	
   103	func getPromptExample(ctx context.Context, client *ai.Client, promptID string) *ai.Prompt {
   104		fmt.Println("\n=== Getting a prompt ===")
   105	
   106		prompt, err := client.GetPrompt(ctx, promptID)
   107		if err != nil {
   108			fmt.Printf("Error getting prompt: %v\n", err)
   109			return nil
   110		}
   111	
   112		fmt.Printf("Retrieved prompt:\n")
   113		fmt.Printf("  ID: %s\n", prompt.ID)
   114		fmt.Printf("  Name: %s\n", prompt.Name)
   115		fmt.Printf("  Template: %s\n", prompt.Template)
   116		fmt.Printf("  Variables: %d\n", len(prompt.Variables))
   117		fmt.Printf("  Created: %s\n", prompt.CreatedAt)
   118		fmt.Printf("  Updated: %s\n", prompt.UpdatedAt)
   119		fmt.Printf("  Version: %d\n", prompt.Version)
   120	
   121		return prompt
   122	}
   123	
   124	func updatePromptExample(ctx context.Context, client *ai.Client, promptID string) {
   125		fmt.Println("\n=== Updating a prompt ===")
   126	
   127		// Define the fields to update
   128		newName := "Enhanced Product Description Generator"
   129		newTemplate := "Write a compelling and SEO-friendly description for {{product_name}} that highlights its {{feature}} and appeals to {{target_audience}}. Include at least 3 benefits."
   130		
   131		updateRequest := &ai.UpdatePromptRequest{
   132			Name:     &newName,
   133			Template: &newTemplate,
   134			Parameters: map[string]interface{}{
   135				"temperature": 0.8,
   136				"max_tokens":  500,
   137			},
   138			Tags: []string{"e-commerce", "marketing", "product", "seo"},
   139		}
   140	
   141		prompt, err := client.UpdatePrompt(ctx, promptID, updateRequest)
   142		if err != nil {
   143			fmt.Printf("Error updating prompt: %v\n", err)
   144			return
   145		}
   146	
   147		fmt.Printf("Updated prompt:\n")
   148		fmt.Printf("  ID: %s\n", prompt.ID)
   149		fmt.Printf("  Name: %s\n", prompt.Name)
   150		fmt.Printf("  Template: %s\n", prompt.Template)
   151		fmt.Printf("  Tags: %v\n", prompt.Tags)
   152		fmt.Printf("  Version: %d\n", prompt.Version)
   153	}
   154	
   155	func listPromptsExample(ctx context.Context, client *ai.Client) {
   156		fmt.Println("\n=== Listing prompts ===")
   157	
   158		// Define filter options
   159		options := &ai.ListPromptsOptions{
   160			Tags:       []string{"marketing"},
   161			MaxResults: 10,
   162		}
   163	
   164		prompts, nextToken, err := client.ListPrompts(ctx, options)
   165		if err != nil {
   166			fmt.Printf("Error listing prompts: %v\n", err)
   167			return
   168		}
   169	
   170		fmt.Printf("Retrieved %d prompts:\n", len(prompts))
   171		for i, p := range prompts {
   172			fmt.Printf("%d. %s (ID: %s)\n", i+1, p.Name, p.ID)
   173		}
   174	
   175		if nextToken != "" {
   176			fmt.Printf("More results available with next token: %s\n", nextToken)
   177		}
   178	}
   179	
   180	func deletePromptExample(ctx context.Context, client *ai.Client, promptID string) {
   181		fmt.Println("\n=== Deleting a prompt ===")
   182	
   183		err := client.DeletePrompt(ctx, promptID)
   184		if err != nil {
   185			fmt.Printf("Error deleting prompt: %v\n", err)
   186			return
   187		}
   188	
   189		fmt.Printf("Successfully deleted prompt with ID: %s\n", promptID)
   190	}

1	// Package ai provides a Go client for interacting with the Atriumn AI API.
     2	// It enables managing prompts and related configurations through a simple, idiomatic Go interface.
     3	package ai
     4	
     5	import (
     6		"bytes"
     7		"context"
     8		"encoding/json"
     9		"fmt"
    10		"io"
    11		"net/http"
    12		"net/url"
    13		"strconv"
    14		"time"
    15	
    16		"github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/internal/clientutil"
    17	)
    18	
    19	const (
    20		// DefaultTimeout is the default timeout for API requests
    21		DefaultTimeout = 10 * time.Second
    22	
    23		// DefaultUserAgent is the user agent sent in requests
    24		DefaultUserAgent = "atriumn-ai-client/1.0"
    25	)
    26	
    27	// Client is the main API client for Atriumn AI Service.
    28	// It handles communication with the API endpoints for prompt management.
    29	type Client struct {
    30		// BaseURL is the base URL of the Atriumn AI API
    31		BaseURL *url.URL
    32	
    33		// HTTPClient is the HTTP client used for making requests
    34		HTTPClient *http.Client
    35	
    36		// UserAgent is the user agent sent with each request
    37		UserAgent string
    38	}
    39	
    40	// NewClient creates a new Atriumn AI API client with the specified base URL.
    41	// It returns an error if the provided URL cannot be parsed.
    42	//
    43	// Parameters:
    44	//   - baseURL: The base URL for the Atriumn AI API (required)
    45	//
    46	// Returns:
    47	//   - *Client: A configured AI client instance
    48	//   - error: An error if the URL cannot be parsed
    49	func NewClient(baseURL string) (*Client, error) {
    50		parsedURL, err := url.Parse(baseURL)
    51		if err != nil {
    52			return nil, fmt.Errorf("invalid base URL: %w", err)
    53		}
    54	
    55		return &Client{
    56			BaseURL:    parsedURL,
    57			HTTPClient: &http.Client{Timeout: DefaultTimeout},
    58			UserAgent:  DefaultUserAgent,
    59		}, nil
    60	}
    61	
    62	// ClientOption is a function that configures a Client.
    63	// It is used with NewClientWithOptions to customize the client behavior.
    64	type ClientOption func(*Client)
    65	
    66	// WithHTTPClient sets the HTTP client for the API client.
    67	// This can be used to customize timeouts, transport settings, or to inject
    68	// middleware/interceptors for testing or monitoring.
    69	//
    70	// Parameters:
    71	//   - httpClient: The custom HTTP client to use for making API requests
    72	//
    73	// Returns:
    74	//   - ClientOption: A functional option to configure the client
    75	func WithHTTPClient(httpClient *http.Client) ClientOption {
    76		return func(c *Client) {
    77			c.HTTPClient = httpClient
    78		}
    79	}
    80	
    81	// WithUserAgent sets the user agent for the API client.
    82	// This string is sent with each request to identify the client.
    83	//
    84	// Parameters:
    85	//   - userAgent: The user agent string to send with API requests
    86	//
    87	// Returns:
    88	//   - ClientOption: A functional option to configure the client
    89	func WithUserAgent(userAgent string) ClientOption {
    90		return func(c *Client) {
    91			c.UserAgent = userAgent
    92		}
    93	}
    94	
    95	// NewClientWithOptions creates a new client with custom options.
    96	// It allows for flexible configuration of the client through functional options.
    97	//
    98	// Parameters:
    99	//   - baseURL: The base URL for the Atriumn AI API (required)
   100	//   - options: A variadic list of ClientOption functions to customize the client
   101	//
   102	// Returns:
   103	//   - *Client: A configured AI client instance
   104	//   - error: An error if the URL cannot be parsed
   105	func NewClientWithOptions(baseURL string, options ...ClientOption) (*Client, error) {
   106		client, err := NewClient(baseURL)
   107		if err != nil {
   108			return nil, err
   109		}
   110	
   111		for _, option := range options {
   112			option(client)
   113		}
   114	
   115		return client, nil
   116	}
   117	
   118	// newRequest creates an API request with the specified method, path, and body
   119	func (c *Client) newRequest(ctx context.Context, method, path string, body interface{}) (*http.Request, error) {
   120		u := c.BaseURL.JoinPath(path)
   121	
   122		var buf io.ReadWriter
   123		if body != nil {
   124			buf = new(bytes.Buffer)
   125			err := json.NewEncoder(buf).Encode(body)
   126			if err != nil {
   127				return nil, err
   128			}
   129		}
   130	
   131		req, err := http.NewRequestWithContext(ctx, method, u.String(), buf)
   132		if err != nil {
   133			return nil, err
   134		}
   135	
   136		if body != nil {
   137			req.Header.Set("Content-Type", "application/json")
   138		}
   139		req.Header.Set("Accept", "application/json")
   140		req.Header.Set("User-Agent", c.UserAgent)
   141	
   142		return req, nil
   143	}
   144	
   145	// do sends an API request and returns the API response
   146	func (c *Client) do(req *http.Request, v interface{}) (*http.Response, error) {
   147		return clientutil.ExecuteRequest(req.Context(), c.HTTPClient, req, v)
   148	}
   149	
   150	// CreatePrompt creates a new prompt in the Atriumn AI system.
   151	//
   152	// Parameters:
   153	//   - ctx: Context for the API request
   154	//   - request: CreatePromptRequest containing prompt details
   155	//
   156	// Returns:
   157	//   - *Prompt: The created prompt
   158	//   - error: An error if the operation fails
   159	func (c *Client) CreatePrompt(ctx context.Context, request *CreatePromptRequest) (*Prompt, error) {
   160		req, err := c.newRequest(ctx, http.MethodPost, "/prompts", request)
   161		if err != nil {
   162			return nil, err
   163		}
   164	
   165		var resp PromptResponse
   166		_, err = c.do(req, &resp)
   167		if err != nil {
   168			return nil, err
   169		}
   170	
   171		return &resp.Prompt, nil
   172	}
   173	
   174	// GetPrompt retrieves a prompt by its ID.
   175	//
   176	// Parameters:
   177	//   - ctx: Context for the API request
   178	//   - promptID: ID of the prompt to retrieve
   179	//
   180	// Returns:
   181	//   - *Prompt: The retrieved prompt
   182	//   - error: An error if the operation fails
   183	func (c *Client) GetPrompt(ctx context.Context, promptID string) (*Prompt, error) {
   184		path := fmt.Sprintf("/prompts/%s", promptID)
   185		req, err := c.newRequest(ctx, http.MethodGet, path, nil)
   186		if err != nil {
   187			return nil, err
   188		}
   189	
   190		var resp PromptResponse
   191		_, err = c.do(req, &resp)
   192		if err != nil {
   193			return nil, err
   194		}
   195	
   196		return &resp.Prompt, nil
   197	}
   198	
   199	// UpdatePrompt updates an existing prompt.
   200	//
   201	// Parameters:
   202	//   - ctx: Context for the API request
   203	//   - promptID: ID of the prompt to update
   204	//   - request: UpdatePromptRequest containing the fields to update
   205	//
   206	// Returns:
   207	//   - *Prompt: The updated prompt
   208	//   - error: An error if the operation fails
   209	func (c *Client) UpdatePrompt(ctx context.Context, promptID string, request *UpdatePromptRequest) (*Prompt, error) {
   210		path := fmt.Sprintf("/prompts/%s", promptID)
   211		req, err := c.newRequest(ctx, http.MethodPut, path, request)
   212		if err != nil {
   213			return nil, err
   214		}
   215	
   216		var resp PromptResponse
   217		_, err = c.do(req, &resp)
   218		if err != nil {
   219			return nil, err
   220		}
   221	
   222		return &resp.Prompt, nil
   223	}
   224	
   225	// DeletePrompt deletes a prompt by its ID.
   226	//
   227	// Parameters:
   228	//   - ctx: Context for the API request
   229	//   - promptID: ID of the prompt to delete
   230	//
   231	// Returns:
   232	//   - error: An error if the operation fails
   233	func (c *Client) DeletePrompt(ctx context.Context, promptID string) error {
   234		path := fmt.Sprintf("/prompts/%s", promptID)
   235		req, err := c.newRequest(ctx, http.MethodDelete, path, nil)
   236		if err != nil {
   237			return err
   238		}
   239	
   240		_, err = c.do(req, nil)
   241		return err
   242	}
   243	
   244	// ListPrompts retrieves a list of prompts with optional filtering and pagination.
   245	//
   246	// Parameters:
   247	//   - ctx: Context for the API request
   248	//   - options: Optional ListPromptsOptions for filtering and pagination
   249	//
   250	// Returns:
   251	//   - []Prompt: The list of prompts
   252	//   - string: The next token for pagination (empty if no more pages)
   253	//   - error: An error if the operation fails
   254	func (c *Client) ListPrompts(ctx context.Context, options *ListPromptsOptions) ([]Prompt, string, error) {
   255		// Create the request with base path
   256		req, err := c.newRequest(ctx, http.MethodGet, "/prompts", nil)
   257		if err != nil {
   258			return nil, "", err
   259		}
   260	
   261		// Add query parameters if options are provided
   262		if options != nil {
   263			q := req.URL.Query()
   264			
   265			if options.ModelID != "" {
   266				q.Set("modelId", options.ModelID)
   267			}
   268			
   269			if len(options.Tags) > 0 {
   270				for _, tag := range options.Tags {
   271					q.Add("tags", tag)
   272				}
   273			}
   274			
   275			if options.MaxResults > 0 {
   276				q.Set("maxResults", strconv.Itoa(options.MaxResults))
   277			}
   278			
   279			if options.NextToken != "" {
   280				q.Set("nextToken", options.NextToken)
   281			}
   282			
   283			// Set the updated query parameters
   284			req.URL.RawQuery = q.Encode()
   285		}
   286	
   287		var resp PromptsResponse
   288		_, err = c.do(req, &resp)
   289		if err != nil {
   290			return nil, "", err
   291		}
   292	
   293		return resp.Prompts, resp.NextToken, nil
   294	}

1	// Package clientutil provides common utilities for Atriumn API clients.
     2	// It includes shared HTTP request execution and error handling functionality.
     3	package clientutil
     4	
     5	import (
     6		"bytes"
     7		"context"
     8		"encoding/json"
     9		"fmt"
    10		"io"
    11		"net/http"
    12		"net/url"
    13	
    14		"github.com/atriumn/atriumn-sdk-go/internal/apierror"
    15	)
    16	
    17	// ExecuteRequest sends an API request and returns the API response.
    18	// It handles:
    19	// - Sending the request using httpClient.Do(req)
    20	// - Network error handling and wrapping into apierror.ErrorResponse
    21	// - Reading the response body exactly once
    22	// - Closing the response body
    23	// - Status code checking
    24	// - Parsing error responses into apierror.ErrorResponse
    25	// - Generating fallback error messages for empty/unparsable error responses
    26	// - Unmarshalling successful responses into the provided value
    27	func ExecuteRequest(ctx context.Context, httpClient *http.Client, req *http.Request, v interface{}) (*http.Response, error) {
    28		// Send the request
    29		resp, err := httpClient.Do(req)
    30		if err != nil {
    31			// Handle network-level errors
    32			if urlErr, ok := err.(*url.Error); ok {
    33				if urlErr.Timeout() {
    34					return nil, &apierror.ErrorResponse{
    35						ErrorCode:   "request_timeout",
    36						Description: "The request timed out. Please check your network connection and try again.",
    37					}
    38				} else if urlErr.Temporary() {
    39					return nil, &apierror.ErrorResponse{
    40						ErrorCode:   "temporary_error",
    41						Description: "A temporary network error occurred. Please try again later.",
    42					}
    43				}
    44			}
    45			return nil, &apierror.ErrorResponse{
    46				ErrorCode:   "network_error",
    47				Description: fmt.Sprintf("Failed to connect to the service: %v", err),
    48			}
    49		}
    50		defer func() { _ = resp.Body.Close() }()
    51	
    52		// Read the response body
    53		bodyBytes, err := io.ReadAll(resp.Body)
    54		if err != nil {
    55			return resp, &apierror.ErrorResponse{
    56				ErrorCode:   "read_error",
    57				Description: fmt.Sprintf("Failed to read response body: %v", err),
    58			}
    59		}
    60		
    61		// Reset the body with a new ReadCloser for further processing if needed
    62		resp.Body = io.NopCloser(bytes.NewBuffer(bodyBytes))
    63	
    64		// Handle non-success status codes
    65		if resp.StatusCode < 200 || resp.StatusCode >= 300 {
    66			var errResp apierror.ErrorResponse
    67	
    68			// Try to unmarshal the error response
    69			if len(bodyBytes) > 0 {
    70				if jsonErr := json.Unmarshal(bodyBytes, &errResp); jsonErr == nil && 
    71	               (errResp.ErrorCode != "" || errResp.Description != "") {
    72					// Successfully parsed error with at least some data
    73					return nil, &errResp
    74				}
    75			}
    76	
    77			// Create a user-friendly error based on status code if parsing failed
    78			// or the error response was empty
    79			switch resp.StatusCode {
    80			case http.StatusBadRequest:
    81				errResp.ErrorCode = "bad_request"
    82				errResp.Description = "The request was invalid. Please check your input and try again."
    83			case http.StatusUnauthorized:
    84				errResp.ErrorCode = "unauthorized"
    85				errResp.Description = "Authentication failed. Please check your credentials or login again."
    86			case http.StatusForbidden:
    87				errResp.ErrorCode = "forbidden"
    88				errResp.Description = "You don't have permission to access this resource."
    89			case http.StatusNotFound:
    90				errResp.ErrorCode = "not_found"
    91				errResp.Description = "The requested resource was not found."
    92			case http.StatusTooManyRequests:
    93				errResp.ErrorCode = "rate_limited"
    94				errResp.Description = "Too many requests. Please try again later."
    95			case http.StatusInternalServerError, http.StatusBadGateway, http.StatusServiceUnavailable, http.StatusGatewayTimeout:
    96				errResp.ErrorCode = "server_error"
    97				errResp.Description = "The service is currently unavailable. Please try again later."
    98			default:
    99				errResp.ErrorCode = "unknown_error"
   100				errResp.Description = fmt.Sprintf("Unexpected HTTP status: %d", resp.StatusCode)
   101			}
   102	
   103			// Include response body for unknown errors if available
   104			if errResp.ErrorCode == "unknown_error" && len(bodyBytes) > 0 {
   105				errResp.Description += fmt.Sprintf(" Body: %s", string(bodyBytes))
   106			}
   107	
   108			return nil, &errResp
   109		}
   110	
   111		// Handle successful response
   112		if v != nil && len(bodyBytes) > 0 {
   113			err = json.Unmarshal(bodyBytes, v)
   114			if err != nil {
   115				return nil, &apierror.ErrorResponse{
   116					ErrorCode:   "parse_error",
   117					Description: fmt.Sprintf("Failed to parse the successful response: %v", err),
   118				}
   119			}
   120		}
   121	
   122		return resp, nil
   123	}

1	// Package apierror provides common error handling for Atriumn API clients.
     2	// It defines the standard error response structure used across different Atriumn APIs.
     3	package apierror
     4	
     5	import "fmt"
     6	
     7	// ErrorResponse represents a standard error response from Atriumn APIs.
     8	// It contains the error code and an optional description returned by the API.
     9	type ErrorResponse struct {
    10		ErrorCode   string `json:"error"`
    11		Description string `json:"error_description,omitempty"`
    12	}
    13	
    14	// Error satisfies the error interface by returning a formatted error message.
    15	// If a description is available, it will be included in the error message.
    16	func (e *ErrorResponse) Error() string {
    17		if e.Description != "" {
    18			return fmt.Sprintf("%s: %s", e.ErrorCode, e.Description)
    19		}
    20		return e.ErrorCode
    21	}

# Atriumn SDK for Go: Repository Boundaries

This document outlines the purpose, responsibilities, and boundaries of the `atriumn-sdk-go` repository within the broader Atriumn system architecture.

## Core Purpose

### Primary Business Functions
The `atriumn-sdk-go` repository serves as the official Go SDK for Atriumn services, providing client libraries that enable Go applications to seamlessly integrate with Atriumn's backend services. Its primary functions include:

1. **Service Client Implementations** - Providing idiomatic Go clients for all Atriumn API services
2. **Authentication Handling** - Managing authentication flows and token handling
3. **Error Standardization** - Providing consistent error handling across different service clients
4. **Request/Response Abstractions** - Abstracting HTTP-level details behind clean Go interfaces
5. **Type Safety** - Ensuring type-safe interactions with Atriumn APIs

### Key Problems Solved
This repository solves several critical problems for Atriumn's Go ecosystem:

1. **Abstraction of API Complexity** - Shields developers from low-level HTTP details, authentication complexities, and error handling
2. **Code Reusability** - Eliminates duplicate client code across Go applications and services
3. **Consistency** - Ensures all Go applications interact with Atriumn services in a consistent, standardized way
4. **Maintainability** - Centralizes API client changes, allowing service API updates without requiring changes to multiple applications
5. **Versioning** - Provides a single versioning mechanism for all Atriumn service clients

### Critical User Scenarios Supported
The SDK supports several critical integration scenarios:

1. **Authentication Workflows** - User signup, login, password management, and token-based auth
2. **Content Storage & Retrieval** - Generating pre-signed URLs for secure file uploads and downloads
3. **AI Prompt Management** - Creating, retrieving, updating, and deleting AI prompts
4. **Data Ingestion** - Ingesting text, URLs, and files into the Atriumn platform

## Domain Ownership

### Data Models Owned
This repository owns the Go representation of the following data models:

1. **Authentication Models**
   - Token responses
   - User registration data
   - Password reset workflows

2. **Storage Models**
   - File upload/download requests and responses
   - S3 pre-signed URL metadata

3. **AI Models**
   - Prompt templates and configurations
   - Prompt variables and parameters
   - Model references

4. **Ingest Models**
   - Content ingestion requests and responses
   - File metadata
   - Ingestion status information

### Business Logic Ownership Boundaries
The repository owns the following business logic:

1. **Client Configuration Logic**
   - Base URL handling
   - Client instantiation with functional options
   - Custom HTTP client configuration

2. **Authentication Logic**
   - Token refresh mechanisms
   - Access token caching
   - Authentication header management

3. **Request Building Logic**
   - Request body serialization
   - Header standardization
   - Query parameter construction

4. **Response Handling Logic**
   - Response deserialization
   - Error detection and conversion
   - Retry logic for transient errors

### Canonical Data Sources and Sinks

#### Sources
- API specifications for Atriumn services (external)
- Service endpoint documentation (external)
- API versioning information (external)

#### Sinks
- API client interfaces exposed to Go applications
- Data models and types for client applications
- Error definitions consumed by client applications

## Service Boundaries

### IN Scope
The following are explicitly within scope for this repository:

1. **Client Libraries**
   - Go client implementations for all Atriumn services
   - Request/response models for all API operations
   - Client configuration and instantiation mechanisms

2. **Authentication Mechanisms**
   - Token-based authentication support
   - Integration with Atriumn auth services
   - Credential management interfaces

3. **Error Handling**
   - Standardized error types
   - Consistent error reporting
   - Network/HTTP error translation

4. **Documentation**
   - Client usage examples
   - Integration patterns
   - API references for Go interfaces

5. **Testing Tools**
   - Client mocks for testing
   - Test utilities for integration testing
   - Examples of proper client usage

### OUT of Scope
The following are explicitly out of scope for this repository:

1. **Service Implementations**
   - Actual implementation of Atriumn services
   - Server-side business logic
   - API endpoint implementations

2. **Authentication Servers**
   - Identity provider implementation
   - Token issuance services
   - User database management

3. **Application Business Logic**
   - Application-specific workflows
   - UI/UX components
   - End-user features

4. **Infrastructure**
   - Deployment configurations
   - Service monitoring
   - Cloud provider integrations

5. **Cross-language SDKs**
   - SDK implementations for other languages (JavaScript, Python, etc.)
   - Language-specific design patterns

### Interface Contracts Provided
This repository provides the following interface contracts to other services:

1. **Client Interfaces**
   - Public methods for accessing each Atriumn service
   - Type definitions for all request/response models
   - Error types and handling patterns

2. **Authentication Integration**
   - Token provider interfaces
   - Authentication mechanism abstractions
   - Error handling for auth failures

3. **Configuration Interfaces**
   - Client option patterns
   - Environment-based configuration
   - Runtime reconfiguration capabilities

### Dependencies on Other Repositories
The SDK has the following external dependencies:

1. **Atriumn API Services**
   - Depends on the stability and contract of the various Atriumn API services
   - Changes to API contracts require corresponding SDK updates

2. **Standard Go Libraries**
   - Uses standard Go HTTP libraries and encoding packages
   - Follows Go module versioning for dependency management

3. **Minimal External Dependencies**
   - Limited to absolutely necessary third-party libraries
   - Preference for standard library solutions when possible

## Decision Guidelines

### When to Add Functionality to This Repository
New functionality should be added to this repository when:

1. **New Atriumn API Service**
   - When a new Atriumn backend service becomes available
   - When existing services add new endpoints or capabilities

2. **Client Library Improvements**
   - Enhancements to existing clients (better error handling, retries)
   - Performance optimizations for API communication
   - Additional helper methods for common operations

3. **Common Utilities**
   - Shared functionality needed across multiple service clients
   - Standardized authentication or serialization mechanisms
   - Testing utilities specific to API interactions

4. **Documentation and Examples**
   - New usage examples
   - Integration patterns
   - Best practices

### When to Delegate Functionality Elsewhere
Functionality should be delegated elsewhere when:

1. **Service Implementation Logic**
   - Core business logic should remain in the service repositories
   - API endpoint implementations belong in the service code

2. **Application-Specific Code**
   - Application workflows and use-case-specific logic
   - Custom integration patterns specific to a single application

3. **Infrastructure Concerns**
   - Deployment, scaling, and operational concerns
   - Monitoring and logging implementations

4. **Authentication Providers**
   - Identity management systems
   - Token issuance and validation services

### Migration Path for Boundary Changes
When boundaries need to change, the following migration approach should be followed:

1. **API Service Changes**
   - For breaking changes: Create a new major version of the affected client
   - For additions: Extend existing client interfaces
   - For deprecations: Mark methods as deprecated with comments and alternatives

2. **Model Changes**
   - When data models change: Provide adapters or conversion utilities
   - When adding fields: Use pointers for optional new fields
   - When removing fields: Deprecate first, then remove in next major version

3. **Client Interface Changes**
   - When changing method signatures: Introduce new methods rather than changing existing ones
   - When adding options: Use the functional options pattern for backward compatibility
   - When changing behavior: Document clearly and increment version appropriately

## Component Relationships

- Each service client package (`auth`, `storage`, `ai`, `ingest`) provides a client library for interacting with the corresponding Atriumn service API.
- All service clients rely on the common utilities in `internal/clientutil` for HTTP request handling and error processing.
- The `internal/apierror` package defines common error types and handling logic used across all service clients.
- Each service client follows a consistent pattern:
  - A main client struct with configuration options
  - Request/response model definitions
  - Method implementations for API endpoints
  - Service-specific error handling

## Code Organization Pattern

```
servicepackage/
  â”œâ”€â”€ client.go       # Client implementation and API methods
  â”œâ”€â”€ client_test.go  # Client testing
  â”œâ”€â”€ models.go       # Request/response data models
  â””â”€â”€ README.md       # Documentation specific to this client
```

## Design Principles

1. **Consistency**: All service clients follow the same patterns and conventions
2. **Simplicity**: Clean, idiomatic Go interfaces that are easy to use
3. **Completeness**: Full coverage of service API functionality
4. **Robustness**: Comprehensive error handling and recovery
5. **Documentation**: Clear usage examples and API documentation

# Atriumn SDK for Go: Service Boundary Diagram

The diagram below illustrates the boundaries between the `atriumn-sdk-go` repository and its surrounding ecosystem, including the services it interacts with and the applications that consume it.

## Boundary Interactions

### Upstream Boundaries (SDK to Client Applications)
- **Interface**: Go package imports
- **Contract**: Public methods, types, and errors exposed by the SDK
- **Responsibilities**:
  - Providing a stable, well-documented API for Go applications
  - Maintaining backward compatibility for public interfaces
  - Handling authentication, error management, and API communication

### Downstream Boundaries (SDK to Atriumn Services)
- **Interface**: HTTP/REST API calls
- **Contract**: API endpoints, request/response formats, error codes
- **Responsibilities**:
  - Mapping Go types to HTTP request parameters
  - Translating API responses to Go return values
  - Converting service-specific errors to SDK error types
  - Implementing retry and recovery logic for transient failures

## Cross-Cutting Concerns

### Authentication
Authentication crosses multiple boundaries:
1. Client applications provide credentials to SDK
2. SDK exchanges credentials for tokens with Auth Service
3. SDK uses tokens to authenticate requests to other services

### Error Handling
Error handling is standardized across all services:
1. Service API errors are converted to SDK error types
2. Network and HTTP errors are wrapped in consistent format
3. SDK exposes typed errors to client applications

## Integration Points

### Integration with Other Atriumn Repositories
- **Auth Service Integration**: Token generation and validation
- **Storage Service Integration**: File uploads and downloads
- **AI Service Integration**: Prompt management and AI configuration
- **Ingest Service Integration**: Content ingestion and processing

### Integration with Client Applications
- **Dependency Management**: Go modules
- **Configuration**: Environment variables, explicit client configuration
- **Error Handling**: Type assertions for specific error handling
- **Authentication**: Token provider interfaces

content.content:
1	# Atriumn SDK for Go: Repository Boundaries
     2	
     3	This document outlines the purpose, responsibilities, and boundaries of the `atriumn-sdk-go` repository within the broader Atriumn system architecture.
     4	
     5	## Core Purpose
     6	
     7	### Primary Business Functions
     8	The `atriumn-sdk-go` repository serves as the official Go SDK for Atriumn services, providing client libraries that enable Go applications to seamlessly integrate with Atriumn's backend services. Its primary functions include:
     9	
    10	1. **Service Client Implementations** - Providing idiomatic Go clients for all Atriumn API services
    11	2. **Authentication Handling** - Managing authentication flows and token handling
    12	3. **Error Standardization** - Providing consistent error handling across different service clients
    13	4. **Request/Response Abstractions** - Abstracting HTTP-level details behind clean Go interfaces
    14	5. **Type Safety** - Ensuring type-safe interactions with Atriumn APIs
    15	
    16	### Key Problems Solved
    17	This repository solves several critical problems for Atriumn's Go ecosystem:
    18	
    19	1. **Abstraction of API Complexity** - Shields developers from low-level HTTP details, authentication complexities, and error handling
    20	2. **Code Reusability** - Eliminates duplicate client code across Go applications and services
    21	3. **Consistency** - Ensures all Go applications interact with Atriumn services in a consistent, standardized way
    22	4. **Maintainability** - Centralizes API client changes, allowing service API updates without requiring changes to multiple applications
    23	5. **Versioning** - Provides a single versioning mechanism for all Atriumn service clients
    24	
    25	### Critical User Scenarios Supported
    26	The SDK supports several critical integration scenarios:
    27	
    28	1. **Authentication Workflows** - User signup, login, password management, and token-based auth
    29	2. **Content Storage & Retrieval** - Generating pre-signed URLs for secure file uploads and downloads
    30	3. **AI Prompt Management** - Creating, retrieving, updating, and deleting AI prompts
    31	4. **Data Ingestion** - Ingesting text, URLs, and files into the Atriumn platform
    32	
    33	## Domain Ownership
    34	
    35	### Data Models Owned
    36	This repository owns the Go representation of the following data models:
    37	
    38	1. **Authentication Models**
    39	   - Token responses
    40	   - User registration data
    41	   - Password reset workflows
    42	
    43	2. **Storage Models**
    44	   - File upload/download requests and responses
    45	   - S3 pre-signed URL metadata
    46	
    47	3. **AI Models**
    48	   - Prompt templates and configurations
    49	   - Prompt variables and parameters
    50	   - Model references
    51	
    52	4. **Ingest Models**
    53	   - Content ingestion requests and responses
    54	   - File metadata
    55	   - Ingestion status information
    56	
    57	### Business Logic Ownership Boundaries
    58	The repository owns the following business logic:
    59	
    60	1. **Client Configuration Logic**
    61	   - Base URL handling
    62	   - Client instantiation with functional options
    63	   - Custom HTTP client configuration
    64	
    65	2. **Authentication Logic**
    66	   - Token refresh mechanisms
    67	   - Access token caching
    68	   - Authentication header management
    69	
    70	3. **Request Building Logic**
    71	   - Request body serialization
    72	   - Header standardization
    73	   - Query parameter construction
    74	
    75	4. **Response Handling Logic**
    76	   - Response deserialization
    77	   - Error detection and conversion
    78	   - Retry logic for transient errors
    79	
    80	### Canonical Data Sources and Sinks
    81	
    82	#### Sources
    83	- API specifications for Atriumn services (external)
    84	- Service endpoint documentation (external)
    85	- API versioning information (external)
    86	
    87	#### Sinks
    88	- API client interfaces exposed to Go applications
    89	- Data models and types for client applications
    90	- Error definitions consumed by client applications
    91	
    92	## Service Boundaries
    93	
    94	### IN Scope
    95	The following are explicitly within scope for this repository:
    96	
    97	1. **Client Libraries**
    98	   - Go client implementations for all Atriumn services
    99	   - Request/response models for all API operations
   100	   - Client configuration and instantiation mechanisms
   101	
   102	2. **Authentication Mechanisms**
   103	   - Token-based authentication support
   104	   - Integration with Atriumn auth services
   105	   - Credential management interfaces
   106	
   107	3. **Error Handling**
   108	   - Standardized error types
   109	   - Consistent error reporting
   110	   - Network/HTTP error translation
   111	
   112	4. **Documentation**
   113	   - Client usage examples
   114	   - Integration patterns
   115	   - API references for Go interfaces
   116	
   117	5. **Testing Tools**
   118	   - Client mocks for testing
   119	   - Test utilities for integration testing
   120	   - Examples of proper client usage
   121	
   122	### OUT of Scope
   123	The following are explicitly out of scope for this repository:
   124	
   125	1. **Service Implementations**
   126	   - Actual implementation of Atriumn services
   127	   - Server-side business logic
   128	   - API endpoint implementations
   129	
   130	2. **Authentication Servers**
   131	   - Identity provider implementation
   132	   - Token issuance services
   133	   - User database management
   134	
   135	3. **Application Business Logic**
   136	   - Application-specific workflows
   137	   - UI/UX components
   138	   - End-user features
   139	
   140	4. **Infrastructure**
   141	   - Deployment configurations
   142	   - Service monitoring
   143	   - Cloud provider integrations
   144	
   145	5. **Cross-language SDKs**
   146	   - SDK implementations for other languages (JavaScript, Python, etc.)
   147	   - Language-specific design patterns
   148	
   149	### Interface Contracts Provided
   150	This repository provides the following interface contracts to other services:
   151	
   152	1. **Client Interfaces**
   153	   - Public methods for accessing each Atriumn service
   154	   - Type definitions for all request/response models
   155	   - Error types and handling patterns
   156	
   157	2. **Authentication Integration**
   158	   - Token provider interfaces
   159	   - Authentication mechanism abstractions
   160	   - Error handling for auth failures
   161	
   162	3. **Configuration Interfaces**
   163	   - Client option patterns
   164	   - Environment-based configuration
   165	   - Runtime reconfiguration capabilities
   166	
   167	### Dependencies on Other Repositories
   168	The SDK has the following external dependencies:
   169	
   170	1. **Atriumn API Services**
   171	   - Depends on the stability and contract of the various Atriumn API services
   172	   - Changes to API contracts require corresponding SDK updates
   173	
   174	2. **Standard Go Libraries**
   175	   - Uses standard Go HTTP libraries and encoding packages
   176	   - Follows Go module versioning for dependency management
   177	
   178	3. **Minimal External Dependencies**
   179	   - Limited to absolutely necessary third-party libraries
   180	   - Preference for standard library solutions when possible
   181	
   182	## Decision Guidelines
   183	
   184	### When to Add Functionality to This Repository
   185	New functionality should be added to this repository when:
   186	
   187	1. **New Atriumn API Service**
   188	   - When a new Atriumn backend service becomes available
   189	   - When existing services add new endpoints or capabilities
   190	
   191	2. **Client Library Improvements**
   192	   - Enhancements to existing clients (better error handling, retries)
   193	   - Performance optimizations for API communication
   194	   - Additional helper methods for common operations
   195	
   196	3. **Common Utilities**
   197	   - Shared functionality needed across multiple service clients
   198	   - Standardized authentication or serialization mechanisms
   199	   - Testing utilities specific to API interactions
   200	
   201	4. **Documentation and Examples**
   202	   - New usage examples
   203	   - Integration patterns
   204	   - Best practices
   205	
   206	### When to Delegate Functionality Elsewhere
   207	Functionality should be delegated elsewhere when:
   208	
   209	1. **Service Implementation Logic**
   210	   - Core business logic should remain in the service repositories
   211	   - API endpoint implementations belong in the service code
   212	
   213	2. **Application-Specific Code**
   214	   - Application workflows and use-case-specific logic
   215	   - Custom integration patterns specific to a single application
   216	
   217	3. **Infrastructure Concerns**
   218	   - Deployment, scaling, and operational concerns
   219	   - Monitoring and logging implementations
   220	
   221	4. **Authentication Providers**
   222	   - Identity management systems
   223	   - Token issuance and validation services
   224	
   225	### Migration Path for Boundary Changes
   226	When boundaries need to change, the following migration approach should be followed:
   227	
   228	1. **API Service Changes**
   229	   - For breaking changes: Create a new major version of the affected client
   230	   - For additions: Extend existing client interfaces
   231	   - For deprecations: Mark methods as deprecated with comments and alternatives
   232	
   233	2. **Model Changes**
   234	   - When data models change: Provide adapters or conversion utilities
   235	   - When adding fields: Use pointers for optional new fields
   236	   - When removing fields: Deprecate first, then remove in next major version
   237	
   238	3. **Client Interface Changes**
   239	   - When changing method signatures: Introduce new methods rather than changing existing ones
   240	   - When adding options: Use the functional options pattern for backward compatibility
   241	   - When changing behavior: Document clearly and increment version appropriately
   242	
   243	## Component Responsibility Diagram

## Implementation Summary

I have successfully implemented a solution for Issue #6: Document Repository Purpose and Boundaries. Here's a summary of what I've created:

1. **REPOSITORY_BOUNDARIES.md**: A comprehensive document that outlines the purpose, responsibilities, and boundaries of the atriumn-sdk-go repository within the Atriumn system. The document covers:
   - Core purpose and business functions
   - Domain ownership and data models
   - Service boundaries (in/out of scope)
   - Decision guidelines for future changes

2. **COMPONENT_DIAGRAM.md**: A detailed diagram illustrating the main components of the repository and their responsibilities, including:
   - Service client packages (auth, storage, ai, ingest)
   - Internal utilities (apierror, clientutil)
   - Component relationships and design principles

3. **SERVICE_BOUNDARY_DIAGRAM.md**: A diagram showing how the SDK interacts with client applications and backend services, including:
   - Upstream boundaries to client applications
   - Downstream boundaries to Atriumn services
   - Cross-cutting concerns
   - Integration points

All the required deliverables from the issue have been completed:

- âœ… Component responsibility diagram
- âœ… Service boundary diagram

The documentation is comprehensive, clear, and accurately represents the repository based on the codebase analysis. It provides valuable information for both current and future developers to understand the purpose and boundaries of the atriumn-sdk-go repository.
